loans.name: Nhóm 03 Thôn 10 Quảng Thái Group

texts.en:
Hoa operates a food stall, selling fish. She is applying for a loan to purchase fish to resell. Hoa has been involved in this business for six years. One of the most critical business difficulties that concerns her is the lack of capital.

Hoa is 27 years old, and she is married with two children. Hoa is the group leader of the Nhóm 03 Thôn 10 Quảng Thái solidarity group, which consists of three members. 

This is Hoa's first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.
 
With her business profit, Hoa hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, for her business to do well, and to make enough money to provide for her kids.

loans.use: to purchase fish to resell

loans.name: Savorn

texts.en:
As a farmer, Savorn, who is a 45-year-old married woman, can only make 6 U.S. dollars per day to support her family. Savorn is living with her husband and three children in a community in the Prey Chhor District, Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. For the last twenty years, Savorn has been involved in agribusiness by growing rice on her farm land and selling the crop to local dealers and customers at the market in her village. 

Savorn would like to get a Kiva loan now in order to build a hygienic latrine in her house. She has never had one before. Savorn is very happy with this loan since it will promote good health, a good environment, and better living standards in her house. She would like to thank all the lenders for their generosity in providing such a great loan for poor people like her.

loans.use: to build a hygienic latrine

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a 40-year-old hard-working woman, married to Francis who earns additional income for the family. They are blessed with four children.  Margaret has been operating a grocery business and a charcoal business for one year, earning an income of KES 8,000 every month.

Margaret was introduced to VisionFund Kenya by a credit officer and is now servicing her first loan of KES 10,000. She intends to use the entire amount to buy green vegetables, tomatoes, potatoes and kale to sell to her customers on a daily day. 

Margaret plans to use the anticipated income to educate her children and hopes to become a successful businesswoman.

loans.use: to buy vegetables, tomatoes, potatoes and kale to add to her stock.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is married and lives in Kapalaran, Tambulig, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines along with her family. They earn a living through farming as their main source of income. Josephine helps operate the family farm and sells rice to augment their income.
She had previous loans used for farming and repaid them successfully. She used her income for daily expenses and the school needs of her children. She borrowed a new loan recently to buy fertilizer. 
In the future, Josephine wants to make improvements to her house and the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer

loans.name: Celia

texts.en: Celia is a widow with one child. She runs a retail store to make a living. It helps her support their daily expenses. She also has a rice farm where she grows enough rice for their consumption, as well as enough to deliver to town and sell for a good income. She joined GDMPC recently and borrowed a new loan to purchase more grocery goods to sell in her store. This picture was taken on their farm where she earns her main source of income. She hopes to improve and expand her business to generate more revenue for the family’s basic needs.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery goods to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary owns and operates a retail business selling a variety of goods in her village to earn a living. She has been in business for many years, earning well for the family. She joined GDMPC in 2010 and her previous loans used for her business were repaid successfully. Improving her store is easier with her access to GDMPC. She took out a new loan to purchase additional grocery goods to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional grocery goods to sell

loans.name: Necel

texts.en:
Necel has been helping her husband manage their farm for six years, earning well for the family. Improving her farm has become easier with her access to the micro-finance services of GDMPC, and she has repaid her previous loans fully.  

Necel has requested a new loan to buy fertilizer for this crop season. She hopes to improve her farm so she can have a stable source of income for the family in the future.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for this crop season

loans.name: Rosanna

texts.en:
Rosanna is a married woman with five children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. She is 42 years old and has two children who are in school.

Rosanna's house was destroyed by super typhoon Haiyan, which swept through the Philippines on November 8, 2013. She has restarted her food vending business, and is committed to regain what she lost. 

Rosanna is taking out a PHP 9,521.40 housing loan through NWTF in order to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor to build a house for her family.

Rosanna has been with NWTF since 2012 in her pursuit to rise out of poverty. With your help, she will be able to start once more in a new home. In the future, Rosanna would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

loans.name: Felisa

texts.en:
Felisa works hard to support her family. Felisa is married and has a buy-and-sell fruits and vegetables business in the Philippines.

She requested an 8,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more fruits and vegetables to sell.

Felisa has been in this business for 5 years now.

In the future, Felisa would like to save enough money so that she will be able to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Fernanda

texts.en:
Fernanda is married with six children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Fernanda is 52 years old and has three children who are in school.

She has a food vending business in the Philippines. Fernanda requested an 8,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to buy additional ingredients like meat, vegetables, eggs, etc.

Fernanda has been in this business for four years. In the future, Fernanda would like to save enough money so that she will be able to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional ingredients like meat, vegetables, eggs, etc

loans.name: Sabeti

texts.en:
Sabeti operates a charcoal business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces stiff competition from other operators.
 
With the KES 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase eight sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and she appreciates the support for the previous loan.

loans.use: to purchase eight sacks of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Nina

texts.en:
Nina is 33 years old and married. She has three children, two of whom are currently in school. Nina is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. She has been raising pigs for three years now, and has borrowed four times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business. 

Nina requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. In the future, she would like to save enough money that she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Shien's Group

texts.en: Preah Vihea province, bordering the neighboring country, is the residential area of Shien and his family. He is 62 years old and a breadwinner who strives for a living via crop and animal husbandry. The business that he has had for five years brings him about 40,000 KHR per day to secure the basics for his family. Never having been with VisionFund(Kiva’s partner) previously, he now leads a group of three to get a new loan. As the leader, he will spend his entire loan portion to buy a solar panel for his family. He hopes that his house will have electricity as others do.

loans.use: To buy a solar panel for his family.

location.town: Preah Vihear Province, Chaom Ksan District

loans.name: Rabiu

texts.en: Rabiu is a 18 -year-old farmer from Kofar Pada. As a Babban Gona member, Rabiu is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Rabiu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Rabiu is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Rabiu said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland, and in 5 years, I want to “become one of the most profitable farmers in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Bitrus

texts.en: Bitrus is a Babban Gona farmer from Chiroma. Bitrus expressed that he is driven by one goal; to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Bitrus to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Bitrus can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Bitrus, is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 40 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Bitrus will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland”. With this loan, Bitrus  will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Joanita's Group

texts.en:
Joanita's group is composed of three hard-working women. Joanita is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kaliro in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past six years, Joanita has been working hard to manage her business which sells medications. 

To help expand her business, Joanita has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more medications to sell and will help Joanita generate greater profits and pay rent on the shop. Joanita hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Joanita is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more medications to sell

loans.name: Kipawa Group

texts.en:
Ully, who is from Tujijenge Tanzaniais, in her late thirties, married and has one daughter, who goes to school. She has been in business for two years managing a butcher shop, selling beef and fish. She is also involved in the poultry business, raising 200 chickens for egg production. She is a busy mother, always trying to learn more from successfully people. Ully has business helpers and works from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. every working day, making a good profit each month. .

This will be her seventh loan which she will use to slaughter a cow for her butcher shop instead of buying meat in kilos. With the previous loans, which she repaid successfully, she started the butcher shop, bought a new photocopying machine and more paper. She earned extra income which she used to plow back into her businesses, cover part of her child's school fees and pay household expenses. Ully dreams that one day she will be able to manage a stationery firm. 
Ully, together with other two Kipawa group members will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to slaughter a cow for her butcher instead of buying meat in kilos.

loans.name: Nhóm 03 Thôn 2 Thống Nhất - Quảng Vinh Group

texts.en:
Huyên works in agriculture, raising poultry. She is applying for a loan to purchase more baby poultry to raise and sell in future. 

Huyên is 37 years old and she is married with 2 children. She is the leader of a 4-member group, the Nhóm 03 Thôn 2 Thống Nhất - Quảng Vinh solidarity group. Huyên lives with 2 dependents in Quang Xuong district, a rural town in Thanh Hoa province.

This is Huyên's first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund of Poor Women. Huyên has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. The main hardship that Huyên faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Huyên hopes for her business to do well, for her family to be healthy and happy, and for her children to do well in school.

loans.use: to purchase more baby poultry to raise and sell.

loans.name: Nhóm 04 Thôn 2 Thống Nhất - Quảng Vinh Group

texts.en:
Định  works in agriculture raising poultry. She is requesting a loan to purchase more baby poultry to raise and sell in future.

Định  is 37 years old and she is married with 3 children. She is the leader of a 4-member group, the Nhóm 04 Thôn 2 thống Nhất - Quảng Vinh solidarity group. She lives and works in Quang Xuong district, a rural area in Thanh Hoa province.

This is  Định's first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund of Poor Women.  Định has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. The main hardship that  Định faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit,  Định hopes for her business to do well, for her family to be healthy and happy, and for her children to do well in school.

loans.use: to purchase more baby poultry to raise and sell.

loans.name: Yusufu Tunau

texts.en: Yusufu Tunau is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Yusufu Tunau joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Bitrus, Jafaru, and  Hajara.. Yusufu Tunau is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Yusufu Tunau will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Yusufu Tunau can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Yusufu Tunau is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Vera

texts.ru: Вере 59 лет, вдова. У нее средне-техническое образование, сейчас Вера на пенсии, в качестве основного дохода для своей семьи занимается животноводством и продажей молока, стартовав в 1996 году с покупки скота на сумму 15,000 сом. Благодаря упорному труду Веры в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеется 1 дойная корова. Также есть 1,60 ГА земельной доли, которую Вера сдает в аренду. Совокупный ежемесячный доход составляет в среднем 8, 000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Вера обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 10,000 сом (KGS) на увеличение поголовья скота за счет покупки одной дойной коровы. Доходы от кредита Вера планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины, в будущем планирует закончить строительство своего дома.
texts.en: Vera is 59 years old and a widow. She has a secondary-technical education. Vera is currently retired. As the main source of income for her family, she practices livestock breeding and sells milk. She started this business in 1996 with an initial purchase of cattle in the amount of 15,000 som (KGS). Thanks to Vera's hard work, she currently has one dairy cow on her farm. She also has a 1.60 hectare plot of land which she leases out. Her cumulative monthly income is, on average, 8,000 som (KGS). To further develop her business, Vera turned to Microfinance Bank "Bai Tushum." She is requesting a loan for 10,000 som (KGS) to increase the size of her herd by buying one dairy cow. Vera plans to invest the earnings from the loan in the further acquisition of livestock. She also plans to finish construction on her home in the future.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow to increase revenues from the sale of milk and dairy products.

loans.name: Hajara

texts.en: Hajara is a 38-year-old farmer from Chiroma.  As a Babban Gona member, Hajara is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Hajara can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the national average of 14. However, Hajara is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  When asked how she plans to spend the income she will make as a Babban Gona member, her said, “I plan to use the money  to educate my children; Mikah, Saminu, and  Asamau. My overall goal is to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Michael Angelo

texts.en: Michael Angelo is studying electronics. He chose this field of study because he thinks that this will be very useful since we live in a modern world. He is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders because his parents can’t sustain the cost of his schooling. Michael Angelo is very hopeful that lenders will grant his loan request so he can pay his tuition fees.

loans.use: To pay for his tuition fees.

loans.name: Boniface

texts.en:
Boniface is 60 years old and married to Veronica, who earns additional income for the family. They are blessed with five children. Boniface has been operating a butchery shop for 10 years, earning an income of KES 10,000 every month.

Boniface is now servicing his fourth loan of KES.20,000 and intends to use this amount to buy cows and goats to slaughter and sell to customers.

Boniface plans to use the anticipated income to open another butchery shop in the nearby town and hopes to become a successful businessman with a bright future.

loans.use: To buy cows and goats to slaughter to sell to his customers.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en: Merlinda is a 58-year-old married mother of six children. She started farming to earn a living in Bonifacio, Philippines together with her family. For over 20 years, Merlinda has been able to manage her farm to meet the needs of her family. Up to now, the farm has been doing well and providing enough cash inflow to cover the family's day-to-day expenses. With her generated revenue, she has been able to save for future needs. Recently, she took out a new loan to purchase fertilizer and to pay weeding maintenance costs to improve the farm. Merlinda expects an increase in production to expand the farm and improve the general living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and pay weeding maintenance costs

loans.name: Mwanaidi

texts.en:
Mwanaidi operates a food-selling business, making dumplings and flatbread for sale. She sells from her home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the KES 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and sugar

loans.name: Gulkair

texts.ru: Гулкаир 39 лет, замужем, мать 5 детей. У Гулкаир среднее образование. Гулкаир в качестве основного дохода для своей семьи, с 1996 года занимается сельским хозяйством, начав этот бизнес с 15,000 сом (KGS). В хозяйстве Гулкаир есть 1 дойная корова, 1 теленок и 1 лошадь, также земельный надел, мерою 1,0 ГА, где Гулкаир ежегодно  сажает картофель, зерновые культуры и эспарцет для внутрихозяйственного потребления и реализации. Также Гулкаир реализует молоко, молочную продукцию, мясо и скот на местном рынке. Благодаря упорному труду Гулкаир, ее деятельность приносит около 15,000 сом (KGS) в месяц. В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Гулкаир обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на покупку скота для увеличения доходов от реализации молочной продукции и мяса. Доходы от кредита Гулкаир планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение своего бизнеса, а также в будущем хочет накопить средства на постройку сарая для скота.
texts.en: Gulkair is 39 years old, married and a mother of 5 children. Gulkair has a secondary education. To provide the primary source of income for her family, Gulkair has been involved in agriculture since 1996, starting this business with 15,000 som (KGS). Her business contains 1 dairy cow, 1 calf and 1 horse, and a 1.0 hectare land plot, where she annually plants potatoes, cereal crops and sainfoin for farm use and sale. Gulkair also sells milk, dairy products, meat and livestock at a local market. Thanks for Gulkair's hard work, her business yields about 15,000 som (KGS) per month. In order to further develop her business, Gulkair requested a loan in the amount of 100,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum" Bank to buy livestock to increase her income from sales of milk and meat. Gulkair plans to invest the earnings from the loan into further growing her business and saving money to build a barn for the livestock in the future.

loans.use: to buy livestock to increase her income from sales of milk and meat

loans.name: Isah

texts.en: Isah is a Babban Gona farmer from Chiroma. Isah expressed that he is driven by one goal; to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Isah to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Isah can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Isah, is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Isah will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland”. With this loan, Isah will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Yohanna

texts.en: Yohanna is a Babban Gona farmer from Chiroma. Like all Babban Gona members, Yohanna can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Yohanna, is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Yohanna will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland”. With this loan, Yohanna will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Luis Ernesto

texts.es: Luis es un joven de 20 años de edad, el se dedica a la agricultura de papas de pimiento y de otros productos a medias con su padre, Luis va a invertir el crédito en la compra de fungicidas y en la mano de obra para cuidar sus cultivos, Luis tiene una grande aspiración que es comprarse un camión ya que su padre trabaja de chofer y dice que los viajes para transportar productos en un camión es un buen negocio.
texts.en:
Luis is a young 20-year old, he is responsible for harvesting potatoes, peppers and other average products with his father. Luis is going to invest the loan to purchase fungicides and the manpower to care for his crops.

Luis has a big aspiration; to purchase a truck since his dad is a driver and he says that the trips to transport products in a truck are a good business.

loans.use: to purchase fungicide

loans.name: Mavjigul

texts.ru: Мавчигул уроженка маленького городка Вахдат, который расположен в 20 километрах от столицы. Мавчигул замужем, ей 47 лет. Ее старший сын уже женат и живет с женой у родителей. Он бизнесмен и занимается торговлей женской одежды. Сама Мавчигул работает на заводе по производству муки. Ее невестка Мехрангез профессиональная швея. Она более 5 лет занимается пошивом женских платьев разных фасонов. Однако сейчас Мехрангез не может продолжить работу, так как ее швейная машинка сломалась и у нее нет сбережений, чтобы она могла позволить себе купить новую. Мавчигул хочет помочь невестке и поэтому обратилась за кредитом. Она надеется, что кредиторы Kiva поддержат их в трудную минуту.
texts.en: Mavjigul is a native of a small town of Vahdat, located 20 kilometers from the capital. Mavjigul is 47 years old and married. Her oldest son is already married and lives with his wife together with the parents. He is a businessman, involved in sales of women's clothing. Mavjigul works at a flour production plant. Her daughter-in-law, Mehrangez, is a professional seamstress. She has been involved in sewing various fashions of women's dresses. However, Mavjigul cannot currently continue her work because her sewing machine broke down and she has no savings to purchase a new one. Mavjigul wants to help her daughter-in-law and requested a loan for this purpose. She hopes that Kiva lenders will help them in this difficult moment.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine for her daughter-in-law, so that she can continue her work

loans.name: Samaila

texts.en: Samaila remembers the extreme poverty that his family faced during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona member. Now, Samaila, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Samaila is ambitious and is aiming to reap at 35 bags per hectare this season. He is particularly hopeful because of the improved seed varieties that he will access with this loan. When talking about the future, Samaila said:  “in 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community." With this loan, Samaila is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Ayuba

texts.en: Ayuba is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Ayuba joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Sadik, Abdullashi, and  Naziru. Ayuba is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Ayuba will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Ayuba can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, his said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Ayuba is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Enis Del Carmen

texts.es:
Enis, es casada y tiene una hija de 15 años, su esposo se dedica a atender un taller de estructuras metálicas, su hija estudia y ella atiende su negocio de venta de tortillas combinado con la venta de prendas de enchape como pulseras, aretes, anillos, etc., trabaja de 5:00 a.m. a 2:00 p.m., su negocio surge a raíz de la necesidad de apoyar a su esposo con los gastos de su hogar.
Con el crédito invertirá en la compra de maíz, leña y cal, con otra parte construirá un local de láminas para tener un lugar más cómodo e higiénico para elaborar la venta de tortillas, espera que su negocio sea más competitivo para tener mejores ingresos económicos con los que pueda cumplir con sus obligaciones.
Sus sueños son tener un negocio más grande que le dé la oportunidad de brindar un mejor estilo de vida a su familia y que su hija pueda prepararse académicamente.
texts.en:
Enis is married and has a 15-year-old daughter. Her husband has a metalwork workshop, her daughter goes to school, and Enis works in her shop selling tortillas and also plated jewelry, like bracelets, earrings, rings, etc. She works from 5:00 a. m. to 2:00 p. m. She started her business because she needed to help her husband with the household expenses.

She will invest the loan in the purchase of corn, wood, and lime powder, and with another part she wants to construct a shop out of metal sheets, in order to have a more comfortable and more hygienic place to prepare the sale of her tortillas. She hopes that her business will become more competitive, so that she has more income to pay for her expenses.

It is her dream to have a bigger business which gives her the opportunity to offer her family a higher standard of living and to enable her daughter to take up an academic career.

loans.use: to buy corn, wood, lime powder, and to build a shop out of metal sheets.

loans.name: Mahbuba

texts.ru: Махбуба женщина преклонного возраста, ей 57 лет. Она родом из района Вахш. Махбуба готовится к новому бизнесу. Она собирается начать животноводство. Махбуба многие годы разводит коров для нужд семьи. Теперь она хочет превратить свое хобби в прибыльный бизнес. Махбуба просит кредит в размере 2000 долларов США для купли трех голов крупнорогатых скотин с целью откорма и перепродажи. Корм для скотов она будет брать со своих земельных участков. Махбуба планирует откармливать скот в течение 30-35 дней. Ей будут помогать невестки. Махбуба имеет двоих сыновей, которые женаты и имеют детей. Ее сыновья сейчас находятся в России на заработках, а их жены с детьми живут с Махбубой. Махбуба хочет улучшить финансовое положение семьи с помощью нового бизнеса. Она так надеется на поддержку.
texts.en: Mahbuba is a senior citizen - she is 57 years old. She is a native of the Vakhsh District. Mahbuba is preparing for her new business. She plans to start breeding livestock. For many years, Mahbuba raised cows out of necessity for her family. Now she wants to turn her hobby into a profitable business. Mahbuba is requesting a loan for 2000 USD to buy three cows to fatten them up and resell them. She is going to gather feed for her cattle from her plot of land. Mahbuba plans to fatten up the cattle over the course of 30 to 35 days. Her daughter-in-law will help her with this. Mahbuba has two sons who are married and have children. Her sons are currently working abroad in Russia, while their wives and children live with Mahbuba. Mahbuba wants to improve the financial situation of her family with the help of her new business. She really relies on your support.

loans.use: to buy three cows to start her new business.

loans.name: Zeboniso

texts.ru: Зебонисо 39-летняя женщина с района Дангара. Она имеет среднее специальное образование. Ее стаж работы медсестрой составляет 4 года. Зебонисо сейчас вдова. Она потеряла мужа и одна воспитывает детей. У нее трое дочерей в возрасте 18, 16 и 4 года, а также двое сыновей, которым по 7 и 4 года. Зебонисо трудится усердно, чтобы обеспечивать пятерых детей и ей конечно не легко. Она работает на двух работах. Зебонисо параллельно у себя дома принимает заказ на пошив женских национальных платьев. Сейчас ей необходимо обновить швейную машинку, но так как собственных средств не хватает, она обратилась за кредитом. Зебонисо очень надеется на поддержку. За счет прибыли с деятельности она хотела бы улучшить бытовые условия в доме.
texts.en: Zeboniso is a 39-year-old woman from the Dangara District. She has a secondary-specialized education. She has worked as a nurse for four years. Now Zeboniso is a widow. She lost her husband and is raising her children alone.  She has three daughters who are 18, 16 and 4 years old as well as two sons who are 7 and 4 years old. Zeboniso works very hard in order to provide for her five children, which of course is not easy for her. She works two jobs. Simultaneously, Zeboniso takes orders for sewing ethnic Tajik women's dresses from her home. Now she needs to upgrade her sewing machine. As her personal savings are not enough for this purchase, she is requesting a loan. Zeboniso really relies on your support. With the profits from the business, she wants to improve the living conditions in her house.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine.

loans.name: Caminemos Al Futuro  Ii Group

texts.es:
La socia María pertenece al banco comunal CAMINEMOS AL FUTURO II, el banco está ubicado en la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.
La socia María tiene 50 años de edad tiene 03 hijos y es soltera, la socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de elaboración de zapatos ,la socia lleva años  dedicándose a este negocio el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su negocio ,la socia vende los zapatos a todos sus clientes que le solicitan como amistades, familiares entre otros, la socia desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de materiales como cuero entre otros. 
Los demás socios se dedican a la ferretería ,agencia de viajes ,venta de chocolates y comida, venta de zapatos , internet. 
Los socios en general agradecen la oportunidad brindada y se comprometen a cumplir con el pago de sus diferentes cuotas en los plazos establecidos.
texts.en:
Maria, is a member of the communal bank: CAMINEMOS AL FUTURO II. The bank is located in the province of Cusco, in the department of Cusco.   
The member, Maria, is 50 years old; she has 3 children and is single. The member alternates her daily activities with a shoe manufacturing business. 
The member has worked for years in this business; she is doing well thanks to the effort that she puts into the business every day. The member sells the shoes to all of the clients that make the request, such as friends, family members and others. The member hopes to continue working in order to support her family. 

The member is requesting a loan to purchase supplies, such as leather, among others.  

The other members work in hardware; in a travel agency; selling chocolates and food; selling shoes and providing internet services. 

The members in general are grateful for the opportunity that is provided to them and they are committed to complying with the payment of their different loan installments within the established time period.

loans.use: to purchase supplies such as leather among others.

loans.name: Nuhu A

texts.en: Nuhu A is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Nuhu A joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Nazifi, Musaiya, and  Adulwazau. Nuhu A is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Nuhu A will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Nuhu A can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Nuhu A is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Ayuba

texts.en: Ayuba is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Ayuba joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children.  Ayuba is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, he will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, Ayuba, would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products like sand. With access to high quality inputs through this Babban Gona loan, Ayuba can reap 30 bags/hectare, double the National average of 14  and  earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked, Ayuba said “I plan to use the money I make this year to Build a better home. However,  Ayuba is not thinking about just this year; he  said,  “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community”

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Salisu

texts.en: Salisu is a 37-year-old farmer from Zarto.  As a Babban Gona member, Salisu is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Salisu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Salisu is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 40 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Salisu is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children. Salisu’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Thar Si Village

texts.en:
Located in Thar Si Village in Central Myanmar’s Taung Thar township, this community currently has 71 village customers, 5 of who are CBO (Community Based Organization) committee members who help lead the loan program in the area. This village is located in Myanmar's dry zone, where insufficient rainfall is very common.  Most villagers are Buddhist and struggle finding access to affordable credit, as the state-owned agricultural bank is not active in the area.

In this village, the villagers cultivate crops such as peanuts, millets and sesame. For the coming season, they plan to use their loans to buy high quality fertilizer to improve soil conditions and increase crop yields. The cost of fertilizer is about $15 for one bag. The necessary number of fertilizer bags varies depending on farm acreage and the usage of natural fertilizers, such as animal manure. During the monsoon season, most farmers will spend $200 on farming inputs. The income generated from crop sales is used to support their families and make other investments, such as purchasing livestock.

Pictured above are Daw Phyu, U Sein, U Myo, U Aung and U Sein. They are the committee members from the Kan Aye Village CBO. Included in the photo (second from right) is U Sein, who is 58 years old and lives with his five family members. He bought peanut and sesame seeds with his last loan and plans to use his next loan to purchase fertilizer.

loans.use: to help 71 villagers purchase high quality fertilizer and pesticides that will enrich and protect their crops

loans.name: Za Yat Kyaung Village

texts.en:
Located in Central Myanmar’s Thaung Thar township, this community currently has 101 village customers, 5 of who are CBO (Community Based Organization) committee members helping to lead the loan program in the area. This village is located in Myanmar's dry zone, where insufficient rainfall is very common.  Most villagers are Buddhist and struggle finding access to affordable credit, as the state-owned agricultural bank is not active in the area.

Only a few farmers in this village can afford to buy a tractor to expedite the planting process. Instead of using a tractor, most farmers rent bulls for $10 a day. The cost of bulls and cows is higher than other livestock costs, such as those for goats and sheep. A new loan would enable the villagers to buy bulls, which are helpful for their farms because they reduce the need for manual labor and their manures act as natural fertilizer for the soil. Additionally, after they are used for many farming seasons, these bulls can be sold for additional income.  Mechanization is especially important in this village as many young people who could be hired labor have moved to urban areas in search of economic opportunities.

Pictured above are U Than, Daw Khine, U Khin, Ma Sein, and U Win. They are the committee members from the Za Yat Kyaung Village CBO. Included in the photo (second from the left) is 42-year-old Daw Khine, the mother of four children. One of her three children is still attending school. She invested her previous loan in seeds and fertilizer. With a new loan, she will buy cows to use on her farm.

loans.use: to help 101 villagers buy livestock that will reduce their need for hired labor and provide natural fertilizer

loans.name: Thu Htay Kone Village

texts.en:
Located in Thu Htay Kone Village in Central Myanmar’s Taung Thar township, this community currently has 38 village customers, 5 of who are CBO (Community Based Organization) committee members helping to lead the loan program in the area.  This village is located in Myanmar's dry zone, where insufficient rainfall is very common.  Most villagers are Buddhist and struggle finding access to affordable credit, as the state-owned agricultural bank is not active in the area.

The new loan would help to pay for animal feed and vitamins that would promote the health of farmers' livestock, such as goats and cows. They would also use part of the loan to pay day laborers, who charge $3 per day to help harvest the crops.  Additionally, the borrowers aspire to set up a shop where they can get various farming inputs such as fertilizer and seeds. This shop would help the villagers reduce their transportation costs, as they would no longer have to go to other towns to buy those inputs.

Pictured above are U Thein, Daw Aye, Daw Kyi, Daw Chaw, and Daw Swe. They are committee members from the Thu Htay Kone Village CBO. Included in the photo (third from the left) is U Thein, who is a 21-year-old single farmer. He both farms and taps toddy-palm so that he can sell palm sugar. Sometimes, he also tutors children in the village. He spent his previous loan on labor that he hired at harvest.  He wants to use his new loan to buy fertilizer, which is important to improve soil conditions and therefore boost yields.

loans.use: to help 38 villagers buy animal feed and vitamins for their livestock and hire labor, which will make planting and harvesting more efficient

loans.name: Chaung Son (West) Village

texts.en:
This community is located in West Chaung Sone Village in Central Myanmar’s Thaung Thar township.  There are 93 village customers, five of whom are Community Based Organization members who oversee the loan program. This village is located in one of Myanmar's dry zones where insufficient rainfall is common.  Most villagers are Buddhist and struggle finding access to affordable credit, as the state-owned agricultural bank is not active in the area.

Most farmers in this village grow beans, sesame, and groundnuts.  This new loan would help village members purchase fertilizer and pesticides, investments that would improve crop yields and therefore crop sales. This additional income will help villagers buy the diesel required to fuel their water pumps, which pump water to people's homes and fields. Because drought it common in Myanmar's dry zones, the ability to pump water is very important.  Currently, villagers are struggling to buy five gallons of diesel, which costs $25, to run the water pump every day.

Picture above are U San, U Latt, U Tin, U San, and U Myint, the committee members from West Chaung Sone Village CBO.  Included in the photo (farthest to the left) is 49 year-old U Myint, the father of five children. His main business is cultivating crops such as peanuts, groundnuts and sesame. He also sells palm sugar generated from his toddy-palms plants. Last year, he used his loan to buy peanut seeds for his farm.  This year, he plans to buy fertilizer to enrich his soil.

loans.use: To help 93 villagers buy fertilizer and pesticides to enrich and protect their crops

loans.name: Than Man Taw Village

texts.en:
This community is located in Central Myanmar’s Thaung Thar township. This village has 40 loan clients, 7 of whom are Community Based Organization (CBO) committee members who oversee the loan process. Members of this village generate income by cultivating crops, such as sesame and beans, and raising livestock, such as pigs and goats. This village is located in Myanmar's dry zone, where insufficient rainfall is very common.  Most villagers are Buddhist and struggle finding access to affordable credit, as the state-owned agricultural bank is not active in the area.

This new loan would help community members buy livestock to sell for a profit. People have to pay about $60 for a sheep or goat.  After raising them, they are able to resell these animals for $100, generating a $40 profit with each sale.  Not only can villagers make money by reselling the livestock, but they can also use their manure as natural fertilizer on their farms.

Pictured above are Daw Swe, Daw Zar, U Khin, U Hla, U Myint, U Soe and U Thein. They are the committee members from the village's CBO.  Included in the photo (the second from the left) is 31 year-old Daw Swe, the mother of two children. Her youngest son is only 8 years old and is studying in primary school. Her family generates income through farming, livestock raising, and selling groceries. She bought three grains of peanuts with her previous loan and is planning to buy two small pigs with her new loan.

loans.use: to help 40 villagers purchase livestock to raise and sell for additional income

loans.name: Gulzar

texts.ru: Гульзар 33 года, замужем, вместе с супругом воспитывают 2 детей. У Гульзар - среднее образование, в качестве основного дохода для своей семьи, она с 2000 года занимается торговлей продуктами питания, Гульзар арендует помещение под магазин. У нее уже наработаны постоянные клиенты, ежемесячная прибыль составляет в среднем 30,000 сом (KGS). Также у Гульзар есть земельная доля, где она вместе с супругом выращивает картофель.  В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Гульзар обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на покупку продуктов питания для увеличения товарооборота в торговом павильоне. Доходы от кредита Гульзар планирует вложить в дальнейшее расширение  ее торговой деятельности и планирует накопить средства на покупку собственного помещения под магазин.
texts.en: Gulzar is 33 years old, married and raising 2 children together with her husband. Gulzar has a secondary education. To provide the primary source of income for her family, she has been involved in selling food products since 2000. Gulzar leases her store space. She already has regular clients, and the average monthly profit amounts to 30,000 som (KGS). Gulzar also has a land plot, where she and her husband grow potatoes. In order to further develop her business, Gulzar requested a loan in the amount of 100,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum" Bank to buy food products to increase the product turnover at her store. Gulkair plans to invest the earnings from the loan into further growing her retail business and saving money to buy her own store space.

loans.use: to buy food products to increase the product turnover at her store

loans.name: Nissojon

texts.ru:
Ниссожон уроженка города Конибодом, где она живет вместе с сыном и невесткой. Ей 57 лет. Она занимается вышиванием тюбетейки - национального мужского головного убора. Этой деятельностью Ниссожон занимается 20 лет своей жизни. Еще в молодости она изучила это ремесло у своей свекрови и теперь она обучает свою невестку, чтобы передать их семейное ремесло от поколения к поколению. 
В данный момент Ниссожон нуждается в кредите. Она собирается приобрести ткани и другие необходимые принадлежности для вышивания тюбетеек. Этот кредит ей нужен для продолжения деятельности.
texts.en: Nissojon is a native of the city of Konibodom, where she lives with her son and daughter-in-law. She is 57 years old. She sews tubeteikas - men's national skullcaps in Tajikistan. Nissojon has been in this business for 20 years of her life. She learned this trade in her youth from her mother-in-law and now she is teaching it to her daughter-in-law in order to pass down their family trade from generation to generation. Nissojon currently needs a loan. She is planning to buy fabric and other materials necessary for sewing tubeteikas. She needs this loan to continue her business.

loans.use: to buy fabric and other necessary materials for sewing tubeteikas (Tajik skullcaps).

loans.name: Musa A

texts.en: Musa A is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Musa A joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Basiru, Ibrahim, and  Bello. Musa A is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Musa A will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Musa A can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Musa A is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is a 30-year-old farmer from Pegi.  As a Babban Gona member, Ibrahim is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Ibrahim can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the national average of 14. However, Ibrahim is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to educate my children; Bilya,Dauda, and Salomi. My overall goal is to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Adau

texts.en: Adau is a 25-year-old farmer from Zarto.  As a Babban Gona member, Adau is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Adau can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Adau is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 40 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Adau is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children; Mujadeen,  and Tijani. Adau’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Rukhshona

texts.ru: Рухшона молодая жительница района Шахритус. Она в возрасте 22 лет уже замужем и живет с мужем в доме его родителей. Муж Рухшоны по профессии учитель истории и права. Однако в данный момент занимается строительством. Рухшона сама домохозяйка и нигде не работает. Сейчас она хочет начать собственный бизнес и принести в семью новый источник дохода. Рухшона выбрала область животноводства, так как она умеет ухаживать за скотом и при дворе их дома имеется большой сарай для содержания скотов. Кроме того семья мужа владеет 0,8 га участком земли и на часть этих земель они будут выращивать корм для скотов. Рухшона в качестве начального капитала имеет около 200 долларов США, поскольку скот стоит дорого, она недостающую сумму просит в кредит. Рухшона планирует купить трех голов крупнорогатого скота для откорма и перепродажи. Она надеется получить финансовую поддержку для успешного начала своего бизнеса. Поддержите Рухшону.
texts.en: Rukhshona is a young resident of the Shahrituz district. She is 22 years old, married and lives with her husband in his parents' house. Rukhshona's husband is a history and law teacher, but at the present time he is involved in construction work. Rukhshona is a homemaker and is not employed anywhere. Now she wants to start her own business and bring a new source of income home. Rukhshona chose the animal husbandry field because she knows how to take care of livestock and has a large barn for keeping livestock in the yard of their home. Besides, her husband's family owns 0.8 hectares of land and will use part of the land to grow livestock feed. Rukhshona has about 200 US dollars as a starting capital, but because livestock is expensive, she is requesting the remaining amount as a loan. Rukhshona plans to buy three heads of cattle for fattening up and resale. She hopes to obtain financial support to successfully start this business. Support Rukhshona.

loans.use: to buy three heads of cattle for fattening up and resale in order to start her own business

loans.name: Maria Natividad

texts.es:
María, es soltera, vive con su hija de 28 años de edad, no tiene más ingresos que los que obtiene con la venta de antojitos como yuca frita, tostadas, enchiladas etc., y venta de ropa para damas, caballeros y niños/as, hace 8 años que inicio vendiendo antojitos posteriormente desde hace cinco años incluyo la venta de ropa para mejorar su situación económica.
Utilizará el préstamo para comprar aceite, yuca, harina, leche, azúcar, condimentos y variedad de ropa, de esta manera aumentara la producción de los antojitos y surtirá el inventario de ropa con nuevas prendas, espera ganar nuevos clientes, incrementar sus ventas y ganancias, que necesita para cumplir con sus compromisos.
Sus objetivos son estabilizarse económicamente, comprar una nueva cocina industrial y cubrir las necesidades básicas de su hogar.
texts.en:
María is single, she lives with her 28-year-old daughter. The only income she has is from the sale of snacks like fried cassava, toasts, enchiladas, etc. and she sells women’s, men’s and children’s clothes. She has had the snacks business for 8 years, and 5 years ago she started also to sell clothes in order to improve her economic situation.

She will use the loan to buy oil, cassava, flour, milk, sugar, condiments, and a variety of clothes. By this she can increase her production of snacks, and improve her selection of clothes with new accessories. He hopes to attract new customers, and to increase her sales and her income which she needs to pay for her expenses.

It is her aim to stabilize her economic situation, to buy a new industrial stove, and to cover the basic household expenses.

loans.use: to buy oil, cassava, flour, milk, sugar, condiments and a variety of clothes.

loans.name: Muhabbat

texts.ru: Мухаббат добродушная женщина. Она живет и работает в отдаленном регионе. Мухаббату 44 года. Она замужем и на воспитании имеет 6 детей. Мухаббат вместе со своим мужем занимается выращиванием сельхоз культур как лук, помидор, рис, хлопок и т.п. Она каждый год берет на аренду 1 га земли и выращивает сельхоз культуры. Мухаббат этим бизнесом занимается уже более 10 лет и имеет постоянных покупателей на местном рынке. Она хочет развевать бизнес и получать больше дохода, так как она должна женить сына. Она запрашивает займ на сумму 5000 сомони для покупки семена. Она ждет вашу доброту.
texts.en: Muhabbat is a kind woman. She lives and works in a remote district. Muhabbat is 44 years old. She is married and raising 6 children. Muhabbat and her husband are involved in growing agricultural crops, such as onions, tomatoes, rice, cotton, etc. Every year, she leases 1 hectare of land and grows the crops there. Muhabbat has been involved in this business for over 10 years and has regular customers at a local market. She wants to develop her business and earn more income because she has to marry off her son. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 5000 somoni to buy seeds. She awaits your kindness.

loans.use: to buy seeds

loans.name: Yusuf

texts.en: Yusuf is a farmer from Kurmi. As a Babban Gona member, Yusuf  is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Yusuf can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Yusuf is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Yusuf said “I plan to use the money I make to build a better home, in 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, Yusuf is on his way to achieving this dream

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Aminu

texts.en: Aminu is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Aminu joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Iliya ,Leatu, and Barnabas. Aminu is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Aminu will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Aminu can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, his said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Aminu is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: José Antonio

texts.es:
José de 48 años de edad, es agricultor, estudió hasta sexto grado, ya que para sus padres el estudio no era lo mas importante, cuando creció decidió formar su propio hogar con la que ahora es su esposa, de esa relación procrearon 3 hijos que son lo mas importante para él, su esposa es ama de casa, ella estudió hasta quinto grado, sus hijos ya son mayores de edad, estudiaron hasta el bachillerato, todos están solteros y viven en la misma casa con él.

José se ha dedicado a la agricultura desde hace 30 años aproximadamente, este trabajo lo aprendió de su padre que fué el que le enseño hasta el ultimo detalle para que fuese su fuente de ingreso, para llegar  al campo tiene que caminar medio kilometro aproximadamente, su esposa y sus hijos se involucran mucho, ya que tambien acompañan a José a trabajar en el campo.


Con el préstamo comprará productos agrícolas tales como: abono, veneno para la plaga y semilla.
El sueño de José es tener un negocio grande para obtener ganancias y cubrir algunas necesidades básicas, hacer mas grande su casa y mejorar la calidad de vida para su familia.
texts.en:
Jose is 48 years old, he is a farmer, and he studied until the sixth grade since his education was not of great importance to his parents. When he grew older, he decided to form his own family and that family comprises his wife; and from that relationship they gave birth to 3 children; the most important thing to him. His wife is a housewife; she studied until the fifth grade. His children are already above the legal age, they studied until high school, they are single and they live in the same house as he does. 

Jose has worked in agriculture for approximately 30 years; he learned this job from his father, who taught him everything, to the last detail, so that it would be his revenue source. To reach the field, he has to walk approximately half a kilometer; his wife and his children are heavily involved since they support Jose’s work in the field. 

With the loan he will purchase agricultural products such as: compost, poison to ward off plagues and seeds. 
Jose’s dream is to own a big business to obtain profits and to cover some of his basic needs; to increase the size of his house and to improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: to purchase compost, poison to ward off plagues and seeds

loans.name: Gorret's Group

texts.en:
Gorret's group is comprised of 2 hardworking women. Gorret is 16 years old and lives in the town of Kaliro in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past 2 years, Gorret has been working hard to manage her small charcoal business, which sells charcoal. 

To help expand her business, Gorret has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more sacks of charcoal for sale and will help Gorret to generate greater profits and buy the family's basic needs. Gorret hopes that in the future she will be able to set up a big restaurant. 

Gorret is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more sacks of charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Eseza

texts.en:
Esaza is 16 years old and lives in the town of Kaliro in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past 2 years, Esaza has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells liquid soap. 

To help expand her business, Esaza has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more liquid soap to sell and will help Esaza to generate greater profits and start up another business. Esaza hopes that in the future she will be able to complete her parent's house. 

Esaza is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more liquid soap to sell.

loans.name: Rokiya

texts.ru:
Эту женщину зовут Рокия. Ей 38 лет. Она живет с мужем, тремя сыновьями и дочерью в районе Дангара. Ее муж в данный момент безработный. В семье работает одна Рокия. Она занимается торговлей детской одежды и это единственный источник дохода семьи. Данный бизнес Рокия начала три года назад. Она трудится усердно, чтобы ее семья не осталась голодной.  
Рокия ответственная и трудолюбивая женщина. Чтобы продолжить бизнес ей необходимо привезти сезонный товар. Для этой цели Рокия обратилась за кредитом. Она так нуждается в поддержке.
texts.en:
This woman's name is Rokiya. She is 38 years old. She lives with her husband, three sons and a daughter in the Dangara district. Her husband is currently unemployed. Rokiya is the only working person in the family. She is involved in selling children's clothing, and this business provides the sole source of income for the family. Rokiya started this business three years ago. She works diligently to ensure that her family does not go hungry.

Rokiya is a responsible and hardworking woman. She needs to bring seasonal merchandise in order to continue her business. Rokiya requested a loan for this purpose because she needs support.

loans.use: to buy seasonal children's clothing for resale

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en:
Rachel is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kaliro in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past 2 years, Rachel has been working hard to manage her small mobile business, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Rachel has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more new clothes for sale and will help Rachel to generate greater profits and help her in paying rent where she will station and start selling her clothes in one place. Rachel hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a saving account. 

Rachel is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more new clothes for sale.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria is 55, married to a farmer and blessed with six children. She has managed a hog-raising business in her village for almost five years and earns a net income of PHP 1,000 per hog. She has tried to save income to purchase more hogs to sell. Due to insufficient funds, she would like a loan of PHP 20,000 to purchase three hogs and hog feed. She's hoping that her business will continue to grow and become more profitable.

loans.use: To purchase three hogs and hog feed.

loans.name: Roger

texts.en:
Roger has been making savings for many days to make home improvements, but most of the savings are spent on household expenses for he supports his parents while he is still single. Now he wants to buy additional grocery goods to sell to improve sales and revenue. 

Therefore, Roger has requested a loan so that he can buy more grocery goods to sell and repair their house with the contribution of savings. Roger joined GDMPC this year and improving his business becomes easier with his access to GDMPC.

loans.use: to buy more grocery goods to sell.

loans.name: Algreg

texts.en: Algreg is 19 years old from Gerona, Tarlac. He is studying Hotel and Restaurant Services. He is already in his 2nd year. He chose this course to easily get a job. He wants to finish college to alleviate his family from poverty. To do this, he wants to obtain a loan of PHP 10,000 from the Kiva lenders for his support and to pay for his tuition fee. Algreg is very optimistic that lenders will grant his request.

loans.use: to pay for his tuition fee.

loans.name: Maxianus

texts.en:
Maxianus is a 29-year-old man who is married to Desy, a 29-year-old woman. They were just blessed with an 8-month-old daughter, named Akiles.  Maxianus has a business rasping coconuts at a traditional market which he has been running for 9 years. He continued his mother's business since she started a foodstall business. 

When he took over the business, Maxianus used his own capital to buy more coconuts. He can sell 50 coconuts per day. Recently, there were 100 coconuts sold. His business is improving now. Due to the Muslim people who will celebrate feast of Eid, he needs more coconuts for client demand but he does not have enough money to do so. Therefore, he requested an individual loan of IDR 3,000,000 from TLM. The loan will be spent on more stocks of coconuts.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of coconuts.
